The real symphony happens in the Executive Lounge of the BMW 7 Series. Boasting and boosting Bowers & Wilkins Diamond surround sound system, an optional massage function, a footrest for a particularly comfortable resting position, and an array of eight fragrances, the BMW 7 Series is a symphony for the senses. #drivingluxury Timeline Photos

Tomorrow's luxury, available already today. 
The BMW 7 Series is the ultimate #drivingluxury. Timeline Photos

We will just sit in the Executive Lounge of the luxurious all-new BMW 7 Series enjoying our rear console, which offers a wealth of functions for the best possible comfort. BMW Touch Command, the 7" touchscreen tablet allows for convenient operation of the comfort and entertainment functions. #drivingluxury Timeline Photos
And just like that, you ARE literally the lap of luxury. The all-new BMW 7 Series. #drivingluxury Timeline Photos

The all-new BMW 7 Series was founded in the concept of 'Technological Poetry': The feeling of a perfect interaction between progressive technology and its translation into design. Our opinion? The ambient light glowing from the interior is a sonnet for the ages. #drivingluxury Timeline Photos
The all-new BMW 7 Series: One of those times where 7th heaven is better than cloud 9. #drivingluxury Timeline Photos

Whoever said you have to stop to smell the roses wasn't thinking big enough. The all-new BMW 7 Series executive lounge comes with Ambient Air Package, which offers eight fragrances divided into four categories: "Blue Suite" with fresh water fragrances, "Green Suite" with fresh plant fragrances, "Golden Suite" with warm, rich fragrances and "Authentic Suite" with natural fragrances. 

#Drivingluxury Timeline Photos

Forget everything you thought you knew about keys. The smart key of the all-new BMW 7 Series displays the time as well as the remaining fuel level and current range, service notifications, and the current status of the central locking system, the windows and the glass roof. The key of the future is just one of the many ways to keep you #drivingluxury. Timeline Photos

Some things are no longer just in spy movies. BMW is proud to announce that excluding the USA market, a range of optional extras for the all-new BMW 7 Series will be available as of November 2015, including the first model variants of the luxury sedan with the world’s first remote-controlled parking feature.

#drivingluxury Timeline Photos
Luxury through and through. The all-new BMW 7 Series. #drivingluxury Timeline Photos

With the all-new BMW 7 Series, BMW has redefined what an exclusive, luxurious driving experience looks like in contemporary, pioneering form. Groundbreaking technologies in the areas of lightweight design, powertrains, chassis, operating systems, intelligent connectivity and interior ambience underline its mission to bring together unbeatable driving pleasure and long-distance comfort in a luxury sedan. #drivingluxury Timeline Photos

Big impact with minimum elements. That's the typical BMW design philosophy in its most elegant form.

A place to relax: the Executive Lounge of the all-new BMW 7 Series.
It offers the rear passenger on the front passenger side maximum comfort through a wide range of adjustment options, an optional massage function with combined Vitality Programme and a footrest for a high-comfort resting position. In addition, the front passenger seat can be moved forwards electronically and its backrest folded out of the way enabling maximum leg room. A folding table and the option of installing the Rear-seat entertainment Experience complete the package, crowning the back compartment of the BMW 7 Series as a place of relaxation and retreat. #drivingluxury Timeline Photos

With BMW Gesture Control in the all-new BMW 7 Series, selected functions can be operated by means of defined hand movements. Simple gestures such as 'swiping' or 'pointing' are identified in the recognition area above the centre console and trigger a variety of functions such as accepting or rejecting an incoming telephone call. Volume can be adjusted by circular motions of the index finger. BMW Gesture Control complements the existing control systems such as the iDrive Touch Controller. #drivingluxury Timeline Photos

The Executive Lounge rear console houses the Touch Command system. This removable 7-inch tablet computer allows the user to control the infotainment and comfort functions available in the rear of the all-new BMW 7 Series. It can also be used to play back external audio and video files, as a games console, or to surf the internet. #drivingluxury Timeline Photos

The all-new BMW 7 Series is pioneering a lightweight construction with Carbon Core which saves up to 50 % of weight over conventional materials while on the other hand improving rigidity. This not only ensures significantly less fuel consumption and a lower level of CO2 emissions, but also offers agile handling and unprecedented driving performance. #drivingluxury www.bmw.com/7series-interest

The Bowers & Wilkins Diamond surround sound system offers outstanding studio-quality sound in the all-new BMW 7 Series. Ultimate companionship, like father, like son.

For many owners a BMW is much more than a vehicle - it's a member of the family. Sam Hurly offers a BMW Story that's the perfect proof: it's about Danny and his son, Boston.

For Sam Hurly (https://instagram.com/samhurly), the way Danny goes about his passion is constant reminder that having a companion around while working on your car makes a world of difference. Whether they've come to help work, learn, or just simply to share in the conversation, that second person can be both a motivator and a calming presence. One afternoon, when Sam found out that Danny had begun work on his 1985 BMW 528e, he arrived to find - little to his surprise - that business was already in session: family business.

Between chapters of his studies, Danny's son, Boston received lessons on BMW parts as they were removed from the 30 year old sedan. It's a magical thing, to see a son appear so similar to his father, both in looks and in the joy expressed. And all of this because of their favourite toy. #BMWstories Photos from BMW's post

This year’s staging of the traditional 24 Hours of Spa-Francorchamps marks a milestone in motorsport. For the first time, Alessandro Zanardi, who had both legs amputated, shares the cockpit with Timo Glock & Bruno Spengler who are able-bodied. A team of up to nine engineers have developed numerous innovative technical solutions that allow all three drivers to optimally race over the 24-hours. Photos from BMW's post

When Jeff was around 3 or 4 years old, his parents began telling him that he had a twin. It took him a while to realise that they were referring to the family car.

The month that he was born, his parents bought a 318i. Anticipating the arrival of their first child, they wanted a car that was safe and reliable, yet also one boasting state-of-the-art engineering. Many years would pass, and the car kept going strong (as well as the joke); and as he approached the legal driving age, he began bugging his folks to let him drive his "twin" car, neatly named Seth.

They reluctantly agreed, and the rest is history – the history of Jeff, and his twin, Seth!
– #BMWstories Photos from BMW's post

When you are driving a BMW you are driving more than a car. You are driving the optimum driving pleasure, one that bonds you to both the road and your car unlike any other. This statement couldn't be more true for Samaa Aburomi from New Jersey. Don't believe us, here are her own words!

"I know people say it's wrong to love material things however, I'm head over heels for my BMW. If loving my BMW is wrong, I don't want to ever be right. For me, it's more than just a car. I get real pleasure from simply just driving my car. I can truthfully say that my BMW is my first true love. I'm never getting rid of it."

If the road is an open book, then BMW is a story for the ages. That is why #BMWstories was created, to showcase the special bond BMW drivers have with their vehicles. 

Reem Al-Semirat (facebook.com/alsmeirs.reem) has been so inspired by her family's legacy of BMW vehicles, she has gone into automotive design as well. We are so flattered our designs have brought you so much joy and ignited the creative spirit within you.

Everyone loves a good story, especially BMW. That's why we created #BMWstories, to bring some of our favourite moments you have shared with us to the larger BMW community. 

We are always blown away by how passionate the BMW community truly is, and are honoured to receive the influx of photos from unofficial BMW meet-ups. Meet Nika, Sergey's (https://instagram.com/m5sergey) beautiful BMW 5 Series. Sergey owns several BMW vehicles, all of which - like many members of the community - he refers to as 'sharks'. Although he gets plenty of ultimate driving pleasure from his existing fleet of BMW cars, he has always dreamed of owning a first-generation 5 Series, in particular the 528i driven by Jacques Coulombe in the epic 1980 racing season.

After months and months, years and years, and countless hours spent scouring the internet, Sergey found this exact replica and the rest is history. These beautiful photos, shot by Gleb (https://instagram.com/glebm8/), were taken one early morning in the suburbs of Moscow, and they truly show the connection Sergey has with Nika. We look forward to receiving many more photoshoots with Nika, and her #companion and driver, Sergey.

Back My Wheels - Cape Town to Munich are three mates and this car, Percy. They’ve set themselves a challenge, to drive +18 000 kilometres, from Cape Town, South Africa to Munich, Germany, and recycle this twenty four year old BMW sedan.

The concept originated with a challenge from a friend, who wanted to part ways with his vehicle by returning it to its makers. That idea developed into a recycling project and a proposed trip across Africa and Europe in a BMW 318i with over 500 000 km on the clock. The challenge was therefore set; not to sell it, not to give it away, but to return it to its makers and thank them for the work it had done.  

See how the guys make it through Ethiopia, North Sudan, Egypt, Israel, Ferry to Greece, Serbia, Hungary, Austria and finally Munich: http://bit.ly/1MDIPPl

In 1973 an entire race team drove in cars of matching design - it was the first coherent team style that the sport had seen. The three coloured stripes of blue, violet and red - set against a brilliant white background - would come to characterise the image of BMW Motorsport and continue to define the look to this day. The unbeatable BMW 3.0 CSL Coupés, kitted out in these colours, soon became known to everybody in the world of motor racing, bringing home the Touring Car Grand Prix at the Nürburgring at the very first attempt. #TriviaTuesday BMW Classic. Over the years I have owned Alfa Romeos, lots of them and for the most part they have been extremely reliable. In February of this year I purchased my first ever BMW a Z4. My first experience of owning this apparently reliable and well designed German brand is the hood motor failed yesterday due to water collecting in the hood motor. This is due to extremely poor design by BMW as the hood drainage channels become blocked and allow water to collect and flood the hood motor. 10 mins on google and it appears this is a common fault with all Z4 models and costs over £900 to fix as the hood as to be removed and new hood motor/hydraulic pump fitted. BMW I have never had an issue regarding such poor design with my Alfa Romeos. Why has BMW not recalled this Z4 model to modify the hood drainage channels?

Fuel consumption is determined in accordance with the ECE driving cycle (93/116/EC), made up of approximately one-third urban traffic and two-thirds extra-urban driving (based on the distance covered).

Fuel consumption in l/100 km (combined): 8.8 - 8.3
CO2 emissions in g/km (combined): 204 - 194

Follow the inspiring journey of Alex Zanardi, a Formula 1 driver, a member of the historic BMW Team Italy-Spain between 2003 - 2009, a two-time Indy Car series winner, a gold-medalist at the Paralympics, but above all, a hero and innovator.

After loosing his legs but not spirit in an almost fatal crash at the Lausitzring in Germany in 2001, Alex Zanardi is back with BMW and ready to take on the most gruelling race of his life. No Limits, premiering at the International Mallorca Film Festival chronicles Zanardi as he trains and races in one of the most famous endurance races in the world: The 24 Hours of Spa-Francorchamps.

"Shaun (www.instagram.com/m3nahrich) first fell in love with BMW back when he was at high school. One day one of his friends got a black M3 and it changed his view on what a great car was and should be. From that point on he strived to buy an M3 for himself at some point in the future.

It wasn't until he turned 24 that he bought his first BMW, an M3 with manual gearbox in Space Grey with Fox Red seats. After years of hard work and admiration from afar, he finally had his own.

Owning that car for 2 and a half years, he then set his eyes on a new goal: The 2014 BMW M3 in Avus Blue metallic. 6 months later, it arrived.

Jeff Koons' BMW Art Car, the BMW M3 GT2, took part in the 2010 Le Mans. Koons' car featured the number 79 - a tribute to Andy Warhol’s BMW Art Car which raced in the same race in 1979.
bmwartcars.tumblr.com Timeline Photos

Esther Mahlangu was the first artist from Africa to design a BMW Art Car, in this case the BMW 525i. She painted it using a chicken feather brush in the traditional colours of the Ndbele tribe.

Read more about BMW Art Cars: bmwartcars.tumblr.com Timeline Photos

The 1989 Ken Done BMW Art Car is a depiction of speed, as the BMW M3 has won the most titles in the history of motorsport.
The warmest colours of the design are to be found at the front of the car, right where the engine sits. Timeline Photos

The BMW Art Car designed by Robert Rauschenberg is the only one driven on a public road. Rauschenberg had to knock down doors, trees and walls in order to get the BMW 635CSi into his art studio on Captiva Island, Florida. Timeline Photos
The 1979 Andy Warhol BMW Art Car - the M1 - is the most successful Art Car to ever race at Le Mans. Fun fact: It took Andy Warhol just 28 minutes to paint the car. Timeline Photos

The 1977 Roy Lichtenstein BMW Art Car - the 320i - is the world's fastest piece of art and finished first in its class at Le Mans. Roy Lichtenstein's design reflects the 24 Heures du Mans - ACO Official  - the sun on the driver's door is rising, and it sets on the passenger's door. Timeline Photos

40 years of BMW Art Cars, and it doesn't stop. Before heading into the future, it's time to look back at a few pieces of art. The 1975 BMW 3.0 CSL, refined by Alexander Calder, was the very first BMW Art Car and went on to race at the 24 Heures du Mans - ACO Official. Timeline Photos

This is my 3 year old BMW 1 series and these are my 11 week old babies Benjamin and Jospeh. On Sunday I was driving on the M25 at 70mph with Ben and Joseph in the car when the brakes suddenly slammed on and I lost control of the vehicle. We were nearly in a high speed collision. The car repeatedly slammed on its brakes as I tried to get out of the fast lane. As you can imagine I was horrified. Drivers around me clearly thought I was trying to deliberately cause an accident. BMW Sytner in Chigwell diagnosed a fault in the car which they say they have never seen before and are apparently sending the parts away for testing. They admit this was a serious incident but think it's ok for me to continue using the vehicle. They are showing a complete lack of concern for mine or the babies safety and are brushing it under the carpet. They even had the cheek to tell me that my tyres are worn (no sh*t Sherlock my car has been trying to emergency stop at 70mph). Has anyone heard of this happening before? Is this really an unheard of fault? Is it unreasonable of me to not want to continue driving the vehicle? I've tried to raise my concerns but they are saying I need to go back to MotorPoint where I bought the car from??

***Disappointed customer let down by BMW***

I am the owner of a BMW 318 (petrol) which is a 61 plate. This vehicle was purchased by Harry fairbairn (BMW), Kirkcaldy, Fife 2 years ago. It was an approved used vehicle with only. 18772 miles on the clock. The car was in complete working order and was exactly how I expected/dreamed my first BMW to be.

However after approximately 10-11 months my engine management light come on and the car had to be returned to Harry Fairbairn to be checked over. The fault I believe was a sensor failure in the engine or exhaust area. At first the sensor was cleaned and I was charged for this due to the warranty only covering replacements not cleaning. I was unhappy with this due to the vehicle having very low mileage. I was reassured by the service department that the engine was checked over and there were no concerns.  
Within days of receiving my car back the engine management light came on again. The car was then returned to Harry Fairbairn and the sensor was then replaced under warranty and after complaining I was refunded the money for the repair. 

After this repair my car ran ok up until July 2016 where I started to get a strange mechanical grinding noise coming from the engine.

I took my car to my local garage (D&G Autocare, Dunfermline) and they inspected the engine. They struggled to replicate the noise and they suggested that if it was to get worse I may need to take it back to BMW to have it checked.

Up until January 2017, the vehicle was running fine and only occasionally made the noise when cold. However the noise became more severe and on some occasions the engine management light would come on. However soon as the engine was warm and the car was turned off and then re started the engine management light would turn off.

Being concern that the noise was getting worse I booked my car into Harry Fairbairn, Kirkcaldy again to get it checked. Whilst booking the car in I was informed that the vehicle was to get a Quality Enhancement on the engine.

The diagnostic check was carried out and the quality enhancement was completed (again full details held by Harry Fairbairn). I was then informed by the service department that the noise would be coming from the timing chain and that it would need replaced at a cost of £1200.

Being shocked by this I carried out a search on the internet regarding this fault and was surprised by what I read. I discovered that it was not uncommon that BMW's manufactured between 2006 and 2011 had this fault and that BBC's watchdog actually covered this in 2013. (Link below) In the article the most occurrences were with the N47 diesel engine however it was also being reported in many petrol engines including the model fitted in my car. Further research on the internet showed that many BMW's were recalled in Germany and other countries in Europe apart from the UK. Lastly I read that some customers who's timing chains had snapped and caused severe damage where given a good will gesture from BMW because of the known fault.

Concerned by what I had read I contacted Eastern BMW, Edinburgh to get an independent opinion and explained the circumstances of my car including the condition, mileage etc and told them about my fault. They were shocked to hear what I told them and suggested that I make a claim through yourselves via Harry Fairbairn.

BMW refused informed me that because my vehicle had missed 1 service it would not be covered.

Disappointed by this I contacted a family friend who is the lead mechanic at Peugeot, Dunfermline and asked his opinion on the fault and if a servicing would have stopped the fault occurring. He informed me that a service would not of prevented or even diagnosed the fault due to the timing chain being at the rear of the engine and can only be examined by removing the engine completely. I contacted my local garage D&G and they also confirmed this. They also informed me that they wouldn't expect a timing belt to go at that mileage let alone a timing chain.

I am not normally a person who uses social media how I don't want any other person to have the same experience from me especially when  BMW's customer complaints page on their website states "BMW is committed to providing products and service of the highest standard".

http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/articles/23p5j5wzPtYflS7kFvmKVZf/bmw-deny-engine-failures-are-due-to-manufacturing-fault

http://prestige-german-engines.co.uk/engine-issues/bmw-timing-chain-failure/ Engine Rebuild for BMW N47 & M57 Timing Chain Failure Timing chain repairs on BMW models 118d, 120d, 123d, 318d, 320d, 520d, 525d, 530d, 535d, X3, X5 and 730d - engine code N47 & M57

I have lost all my faith in the brand of BMW and the company of Knights. In May 2014 I brought a brand new 116i from North Staffs Knights, in May 2016 it started to develop a very loud engine rattle when starting up.

1.  Car goes in to be rectified - refused because there was nothing they can do I was told it was a standard acoustic flaw.

2. Car goes in - admission of a fault - turbo is changed under warranty to rectify the noise. 

3. Car continues to make the noise. Area technician states that there is no issues with the car (describing it as a standard acoustic flaw in this model) which has supposedly been repaired under warranty as there was a problem (which still exists). 

4. BMW are unsure of the problem with the car so it then becomes easier to state that the car is in perfect condition and it was designed  to do this. I'm being told it's the waste gate valve and it needs to rattle while it warms up until so it doesn't cause issues with the turbo, yet speaking to independent garages they say it doesn't sound like that, miss diagnostic? 

I refuse to believe that a premium car would be designed and developed with an intentional engine rattle and clunking, the noise certainly turns heads in the car park. 
I've asked BMW UK and Knights BMW on a number of occasions the following questions which they refuse to even acknowledge let alone answer;
1) if this is a standard acoustic flaw why didn't it happen for the first 2 years and 20k miles?
2) if it is a standard acoustic flaw why does it not happens in all the 116i models? And certainly not any for sale at Knights?
3) If it was a standard acoustic flaw why would Knights and BMW spend money on replacing the turbo unit? And when this didn't work refused to carry out any more work!!!
4) why did it not rattle for 2 years if it needed to rattle in order not to cause problems with the turbo?
5) why when I turn the car off and on again is the rattle gone, the car has not warmed up in a few seconds?

BMW uk have told me there is nothing more they can do refusing to acknowledge the questions above referring me back to Knights who tell me they cannot fix my (un fixable) car  as BMW uk won't approve any work, creating a very annoying loop with no resolution.

This is disgusting from a so called premium car brand. The attached video shows the "standard acoustic flaw" of the 116i, beware!

Please respond to me a.s.a.p. as i miss my machine already.

I have always been a huge fan of BMWs since I was a little kid; Truly the Ultimate Driving Machine in my mind. I have owned many other cars and Luxury Brands, but nothing has surpassed the engineering and driving pleasure of owning a BMW. Unfortunately my first BMW purchase has been plagued with constant trips to the shop and constant break downs; leaving myself and my loved ones in danger or in constant fear of being without a vehicle. I have remained a fan throughout and despite my job being at risk, and friends constantly reminding me I should have purchased another brand I have remained loyal. My patience wore thin though after the 6th or 7th break down this past weekend. I spoke with corporate for potential resolution in terms of a replacement vehicle or compensation, and they were very responsive and willing to work with me. This also extended to BMW of Denver who have been an absolute Jewel throughout the process. The Corporate compassion and understanding quickly ended when they deemed my vehicle to not be a lemon and working in perfect order this afternoon. My car has been in the shop over 4 times within the first year and over 7 times for the same Drivetrain Malfunction Error; a well known issue plaguing many BMW's and they refuse to assist me any further. It is a shame for the price of the vehicle you expect to get quality service. If resolution is not an option this will unfortunately be my first and last BMW.....

In continuation to my frustration at BMW service team from 5th April - it happened again just within 3 weeks. Again break problems and extremely bad handling of the issue at BMW Solln, Munich. I wish I hadn't bought BMW, it is just simply getting on my nerves.

BMW....  I have a dear friend of mine that became a widow two years ago.  Prior to her husband passing away, he purchased her a brand new BMW - Which was the dream car she wanted.  

It has been real hard for my friend to take over her husband's business and to care for their only son.  After enduring so much pain after her husband's death, things have been extremely hard for her.

My friend fell two months behind on her car payment and was able to gather the funds about a week ago.  She only has 8 car payments left so she can pay off the car that her husband bought her.   It came to her surprise that the car was repossessed and she advised BMW that she has all of the funds to bring the car current.  

BMW does not want to take the funds to bring the account current.  BMW stated that the car will be going to auction in 5 days - I can only imagine that BMW will make a good profit on the vehicle.  When I was made aware of the situation I felt extremely bad for my friend.    

Taking her car to auction and not accepting her funds to bring the account current is morally and ethically wrong.  I understand she has not met her obligation by falling behind but why can't BMW take this as an isolated case and not want to help an individual out?  I ask that BMW reach out to me so this individual can have the opportunity to send her money and have the account be current. Please reach out to me.

I have included a picture of my friend that shows them embracing his situation of cancer and knowing that it was Terminal Cancer.

I have a problem with my 7 month BMW X1 and BWM thailand do nothing to solve my problem. Unitl now my car was parked in an auth. service center for 2 month.

Here are all the issues I’ve had since delivery of my new BMW, registration HN65 TKU.
 
The vehicle was delivered around 10am Monday 14th December 2015 by a contracted driver who had already driven the vehicle around 160 miles. I was very briefly shown around the vehicle but not properly by any means. When I was asked to sign the paperwork I asked the driver if he was able to show me the specific extras that I had ordered and he was unable to do so indicating the fact that he didn’t work for BMW. So obviously I then had to sign paperwork unaware whether the car actually had the specifications that I had asked for.
 
I live in a very remote village with the nearest train station being just under 5 miles away. The driver was supposed to make his own way there and as a goodwill gesture I offered to drive him to BMW in Stevenage which was around 13 miles each way.
 
Around 5pm Monday the new vehicle started smoking and producing a very strong burning smell. As I have never had a BMW before and I had ordered through Neva-Consultants I was unsure as to who I should call. Neva’s offices were closed so I called one of the sales teams' mobile numbers who was actually on holiday. He made me aware of BMW’s emergency service line which I then called.

After having to explain the problem and register all my details I was told around 6pm that a mechanic would be no longer than 90 minutes. The mechanic actually turned up around 9.15pm. This whole time I was sat at a family friend’s house with my 2 year old son for over 3 hours. If I hadn’t have been near my friends’ house then I would have been sat with my son on the roadside.
 
When the mechanic arrived I explained to him about the smoke and smell. He basically told me that it was impossible for the smell to be inside the vehicle indicating I was lying and that he couldn’t find a fault.

I then drove the vehicle again and the smoke and smell returned so I took videos of the problem and called the mechanic’s mobile. He showed up again saying that he wasn’t sure what was causing the problem and that I should call the garage in the morning. He wouldn’t fill out a form for me as I had called his mobile the second time and apparently a job wasn’t raised through BMW but he advised me to avoid driving the vehicle.
 
I then had to get my Father to come and get me and my son and to help get the vehicle back to my home address which was 10 miles away. I didn’t get back to my house until around 11.30pm. I had a full day off work Monday to wait for delivery of this new vehicle and then by Monday evening had no use of a vehicle and had to arrange for my boss to pick me up Tuesday morning to enable me to return to work again.
 
Once at work I had to call BMW emergency services, Neva-Consultant’s, BMW Specialist cars in Stevenage and Enterprise to try and sort collection of my vehicle and arrange a replacement vehicle. I then had to pay a £50 deposit for the courtesy car.

I spent over 2 hours at the very least on Tuesday morning on the phone to various companies trying to sort out problems with this vehicle and understand where I even stand in this whole situation. I then had to work late Tuesday to make up this time and arrange other people to collect my son from childcare.
 
I received more of a detailed introduction to my replacement vehicle from Enterprise than I did the vehicle that I actually ordered.
 
On Wednesday 16th December 2015 I was notified by BMW Specialist cars in Stevenage that the problem was caused by an oil leak and that they had replaced the feeder pipe to the turbo and that the car was now fixed and ready for collection.

I picked the vehicle up Wednesday evening after work, left my courtesy car at BMW and drove home. By the time I got home the smell and smoke returned so yet again I called BMW very frustrated. I was told over the phone that it was probably just excess oil still burning off yet nobody cared to warn me or mention this when I collected the vehicle.

On Thursday 17th December I drove the BMW to a clients in the morning where I stayed all day and drove home in the evening. I didn't seem to have any problems this day so assumed the 'excess oil' had burnt off as suggested.

Friday morning I drove the vehicle to a friends' where it stayed until Saturday morning. Saturday 18th December I drove the car to collect my son and popped home to get ready to go Christmas shopping with him. When I got home at 12.30 yet again the smoke and smell had returned so I called BMW Snows in Portsmouth where the vehicle was purchased, BMW Special cars in Stevenage where the vehicles was repaired and eventually both fobbed me off to call BMW emergency services again.

The vehicle was collected at 3pm and the mechanic who collected it this time wasn't as rude as the first one and actually suggested that the excess oil story was a big lie and whilst he was looking at the problem he pointed out that the bonnet is also bent and doesn't shut properly. 

I finally got a courtesy car at around 5pm which I had to pay another £50 deposit for and still hadn't received the refund for the first courtesy car! So £100 down at that present time.

All I have heard all week is people saying that it sounds like I have been given a 'Friday afternoon job' vehicle.
 
There is now over 300 miles on the clock of this BMW and I have probably driven only about 50 of them... if that!
 
I have spent so many hours this week wasting my time on the phone to several companies regarding this vehicle and clearly getting no where. I have a full time job and a young son that I should be focusing on not spending my time sorting out problems with a brand new car.

Not only has this vehicle managed to ruin my whole week last week, it also ruined my whole weekend and the problem is still not sorted a week later.

I can't even begin to explain how stressed, disappointed and frustrated I am. Clearly nobody really cares because to them it's just a 9-5 job so as soon as it's home time it doesn't matter! I am so fed up of being fobbed off and ignored so I've decided to make this complaint public.

Dear BMW, we are appalled at the way we have been treated over the timing chain issue. Our BMW has been on our drive with NO engine for over a year. Last November our timing chain snapped, suddenly whilst driving. Luckily there was no nasty accident. However, we had the car towed off the road by a local prestige garage, we subsequently called BMW and were told to take it to the local BMW in Bromley in Kent where it was very likely that we would be offered a repair as good will as it was a known fault. We had to pay £1000 for an assessment BUT were then told that the repairs would cost £10,000. The local prestige garage had said that the repair would cost around £3500 for the same repair of the timing chain. We have since been a dispute with you, our finance company and the financial ombudsmen, because you will not admit to the fact this is a KNOWN fault despite over 600 cases of this being reported in the UK, it being investigated on watchdog AND reports of the fault ALL OVER THE INTERNET. The car was delivered back to us and has sat on our drive with NO engine in it for over a year now while we waste hours writing letters to you and the finance company seeking resolution. After a year of back and forth, in which we purchased a new car, and kept up our finance payments, we decided that we coudl no longer afford to pay for a car we no longer can drive. Today it is being picked up by the collection agency and we are left with NO car and have paid around £15,000 in finance already plus now legal fees. AND GUESS WHAT - they have said this is the SECOND BMW this week they are picking up with a timing chain fault. So, Thanks so much for causing us stress, anguish, and stamping on your customers because you clearly think we are too little for you to bother about. As we have received no apology or admittance of the fact that this is a known fault, my only recourse will be to make sure others no longer fall foul to you ripping them off, I will be creating a website to discuss this particular issue ( I work in marketing and know exactly how to do this) and will be creating a series of viral videos to warn others against investing their hard earned money and savings and being crushed by a company they believed in.
My dream !! <3

Our cars, the ultimate driving machines, such as the way they're designed, engineered, manufactured, and marketed, they provoke various forms of emotional responses.  Sometimes those emotions are positive, sometimes just downright negative (usually from other road users who don't share the same driving experience which happen to also include the other German auto brands.).  But that's OK.  I understand, because way back when I first laid my eyes on an E28 5 Series in the early 80's it is a very positive impression that cemented a young boy's motivation towards having one one day.  So much so that today not only, the passion for these cars are stronger than ever, but also the approach to living and working and generally doing things have also started to take on that of the Bavarian car maker's ethos. A BMW person through and through.

Dear BMW,

I'm Sorry to write to you this but I would like to share my 5 years experience with your Car BMW 5 Series 520d model

1. While driving from Nashik Highway to Mumbai, Car's steering suddenly gets jammed & have to somehow stop the car in the middle of a highway.
2. The left side indicators suddenly stopped working

Regards

Looking at cars you love is nice; but owning them is even better.
Fabian's passion for cars began when he was a little boy. From his position in the backseat, he watched the vehicles that passed and tried to recognise each model just by looking at their headlights. Later, after he and his father went to see the Ennstal-Classic Rally, Fabian became more and more fascinated by youngtimer and classic vehicles. And so the first car he bought did not roll directly off the production line, but it came rather with a great history. He chose the BMW 520i, built in 1987. This photo was taken after his good friend had given him a lift to where his BMW 520i was waking up from its winter sleep. #BMWstories #legends

I recently owned for a short period of time a BMW 520 D, 56 plate. 
The car ran smoothly with no obvious faults, everything you would expect from a car. 
Yesterday 21-04-2015 my car was parked up outside of my home, when someone informed me, it was on fire from the boot. 
Me and a few friends immediately started to tackle the fire with buckets of water and a hose pipe. 
The blaze was getting stronger so the fire brigade were called, when they arrived they tried opening the doors and boot which were completely dead shut, with the fire only getting worse they had to smash the rear passenger window and the boot window to gain access, but this didn't help, they had to use heavy equipment to prise open the boot. 
They began tackling the blaze, which ended in my car being a total write off due to a fire starting from faults with wiring in the boot. 
Due to the fire brigade telling me it was a fault with wiring and how unusual this was to have happened, I looked up electrical/wiring faults with BMW only to find, in 2012 BMW recalled over 1 million of the same models as my own due to the battery cable cover inside the boot being incorrectly mounted. 

Luckily no one was inside of the car when this took place, if they had of been it would have had devastating consequences. 
I understand all owners of this model of BMW were contacted by letter about the recall, but is a letter truly enough when this could have ended in a fatality? 
My partner is due to give birth any day now and I'm so thankful she didn't arrive on her due date because this could have ended lives. This car was bought as a family car, how can BMW justify sending a letter to recall faulty models, when clearly people's lives were at risk? 
If we had known about this we would have had the car straight a garage to have the fault corrected.
If previous owners did not pay attention to the letter about the recall, Surely BMW are at blame to this seems it was such a serious issue. 
This should have been made vital that the cars were returned. 

I would appreciate greatly if someone would contact me on the below details 

Mobile number (UK) - 07514104555

Email: mickey-k-@hotmail.com

Solicitors have been contacted.
My DREAM CAR

I want to share my horrific experience with a 2010 BMW 335d. Should a 5 year old car with less than 60K miles require an engine job costing $4,300? My 1994 BMW 525i lasted 18 years with very few problems. Unfortunately, I don't think BMW knows how to build diesel cars for the U.S., nor is it willing to stand behind its own badly designed products. The following is an email message I sent to BMW USA seeking assistance which comes back with a negative verbal response after 1 week:

To: BMW Customer Relations
Attn: Resolution Specialist Aly
From: Arvola Chan
Date: April 9, 2015
Re: 2010 BMW 335d (VIN WBAPN7C53AA266833)

Dear Ms. Aly:

I last spoke to you on the phone on April 6, 2015 regarding the carbon buildup problem on my BMW 335d. At the time you told me that once it has been determined by an authorized BMW dealer that de-carbonization of the intake ports is necessary, BMW may be able to provide financial assistance to get this procedure done. Now I have in fact recommendations from two authorized BMW dealers, BMW of Mountain View and Stevens Creek BMW that carbon cleanup is the logical next step to resolve the recurring Service Engine Soon (SES) warning light problem. I tried calling you yesterday after receiving the recommendation from Stevens Creek BMW but was unable to reach you. Representative Alex told me that you will get back to me with the decision in 3 to 5 business days. In the meantime, I like to provide you with a documentation of the long history of SES problems in this car, why I think this car is unreliable, and why I think BMW should stand behind its own product.

2/18/2011 SES         20688
6/29/2011 SES         25961
2/29/2012 SES         36735
1/14/2013 SES         48718
12/13/2013 SES         52352
10/13/2014 SES         55112
11/11/2014 SES         55627
1/12/1015 SES         56315
2/20/2015 SES         56988
4/1/2015         SES         57705

As you can see, the SES warning is coming up increasingly frequently. Between October 2014 and February 2014, the car was serviced by Stevens Creek BMW for 4 times, each time under the California 7 year 70K miles emission warranty. During the 2/20/2015 service, a PUMA case (#60790270) was started. When the SES light came back on in March 2015, I called up BMW Customer Relations and talked to Representative Brittany. Arvola Chan

I would like to share my bad experience BMW/Mini service center in Egypt.
It has always been a dream to own a mini cooper and when it happened, it turned to be a nightmare very quickly.Since I bought the car, I used to bring it to the service center 2-3 times a year for an average of 1-2 month each time due to the lack of response of the service advisers and the unavailability of spare parts!!! I was obligated to buy a second car due to the fact that my MINI is not reliable and is not available all the time. I don't want to drag you into details, however I would like to focus on the past 2 service experiences I had with Abo Rawash service center.
THE FIRST ONE: I entered my vehicle on 02/08/2014 with an oil and water mixture in the cooling system, I kept chasing the service advisers for more than 10 days to get the final diagnosis and what really needed to be replace as they were trying to up-sell the whole cooling system!!!! Finally I was able to receive the vehicle the on 24/09/2014 and I paid more than 3,000 EGP, but unfortunately they forgot to put new engine oil and oil filter!!!!!
I traveled for 3 months after I received the car and when I came back, I discovered that the outside temperature sensor is not working and the radio CD is refusing to accept any CD, even the magazine of the CD CHANGER is not working and no one told me although that everything was working perfectly well before entering the service center, but I thought it is not a big deal and it might need to be cleaned or so.
THE SECOND ONE: After, 3000 KM the engine sound was very high and when I checked the oil level, it was almost empty. I checked the invoice of the last maintenance mentioned above and I discovered that there is no engine oil and oil filter mentioned in invoice. I got worried and I called the Eng. Hossam Hamoda telling him the case and that I needed a carrier to take my vehicle to the service center as its basically their mistake. He was very calm and told me that they don't own a carrier and that he won't be able to judge unless I bring the car to the service center by any means i want, because they don't support this!!! 
Is this the expected service from a premium brand?! I got a carrier and went to the service center on 21/02/2015, after a lot of chasing calls and SMSs, they told me that some parts needed to be changed that wasn't mentioned in the previous report as a trial for the usual up selling!!! The case is very simple, it needs an apology and changing engine oil & oil filter!!!
To cut the story short, I agreed to change all the things they wanted to change and they asked for a a down payment that I went and paid on 25th of Feb. Eng. Mohamed Fathi advised that it will arrive in 1-2 weeks maximum, and nothing arrived till now and he advised that we usually experience delays in the parts shipment and things will not arrive before 1st of April!!!!!
I can't take this anymore! I want to return this vehicle to you and get my money back. I can't take the risk of selling it to anyone because it has a lot of problems, unreliable and the service center is not able to well maintain it and make the spare parts available.

From the very first issue of the BMW 528 engine shivers after a very short 1.5 minute drive, more parts of the car were replaced as the car front wheels begin to having cranky noise which steering rack, wish bones, bushes and etc were replaced....
In this such short period Our BMW 528 has been hospitalized and transplanted with new parts...and till now its still in the good hands of BMW Ingress Auto Razak and Hong including Kumar. With the final warranty checked together with further cranky noise coming off from the front wheels and now having the left rear shock absorber leaked... It is rather funny as our BMW 528 wishes to be hospitable with its good transplanted parts...in the warm arms of BMW Ingress. Is this the quality of BMW 528? Shocking to realized that BMW Malaysia replaces only one left shock absorber instead of both side. As per advice from at least two BMW authorized service centers replacement of shock absorber should be in pairs for the stability of the ride towards safety. Happened to be at BMW Melbourne service on 9th Feb 2015 they replaced a pair but here in Malaysia, why only one?
Are we ignorant enough to accept only one? We wrote to BMW Voice on 31st Jan 2015 and was hospitable by BMW Voice Sufian's email 4th Feb 2015 that BMW Malaysia would be notified to response. As per our telephone conversation with Sufian on 10th Feb 2015 that BMW Malaysia would have contacted us regarding our email to BMW Malaysia. Contacted Ng of BMW Lee Motor who claimed that they have done their best to hear our distress. Till date BMW Malaysia never contacted us regarding the matter despite BMW Ingress Auto has advice them... Our BMW 528 is falling apart which is hardly 1.5 years of age. Having some meeting with BMW Ingress Razak yesterday 11th Feb 2015 and was informed that BMW Malaysia would like to close the case by asking us to accept the replacement of the right rear absorber.
Recalling our early experience with our BMW 323 in our early years pertaining to the air con warranty, we were informed the BMW Malaysia did not respond as the staff were on leave and hence no response.. What's for now?
Driving with Pleasure or Pressure with Quality of Parts seemed now our fate of having BMW 528 together with no response from BMW Malaysia. Is this how we are treated? What is the price of this BMW 528? This is the price of Fate....
Our feelings shown above that BMW Malaysia left the heat to both BMW Ingress and BMW Lee Motor. Is this how the local principal treats their agents? What is BMW Voice is all about when there's no response from BMW Malaysia? Similar to our earlier experience the staff are on leave...and could not be bother...
Our final comment is that "This is how we were treated with the Most Hospitable Service from BMW"...believing all the motto, claims, beliefs from BMW website...

Could I get some advice please? Five weeks ago my father brought a BMW 520D from Coopers at Colchester, and paid over £40k for it. After 5 weeks and 580 miles of use, the brake warning light came on. The vehicle was subsequently inspected by Coopers in Ipswich. We then received a call from them, and we were told that some non BMW approved parts had been fitted, and we must have had work carried out to the brakes by a third party. This is of course absolute nonsense. Why would we have had any work carried out by a third party? Why would it even need any work carried out after 580 miles? We were told that all the brakes would have to be changed, as they had the wrong type of grease all over them. Then came the issue of the warranty. We were told that BMW would not cover the cost of the 'repair' so it would be chargeable to my father. At this point, I'd stress that the car was five weeks old, had done 580 miles, and we'd never had any work carried out to it. So, to be told we'd be charged was upsetting and, quite frankly, insulting. Feeling pretty aggrieved, we're of the opinion that the car was driven off the forecourt of Coopers at Colchester with a brakes issue. What other explanation is there? Clearly, Coopers are of the opinion the brakes issue has been caused by us, but they're not applying any logic to that view-point. Why would we? It makes no sense. Yes, I'm sure that BMW have quality control, but it seems that Coopers are taking the stance that it is easier to apportion blame to the customer rather than even consider the fact that there could have been an issue before we received the car. Once again, please bear in mind the mileage of 580 miles!!! So, feeling aggrieved, we refused to pay for the replacement of the brakes, and countered that with the fact we feel we should be entitled to some form of compensation. After numerous discussions with the manufacturer and Coopers of Colchester, we haven't been able to agree. To settle the matter, we had asked for................the brakes to be repaired, a GardX car protection valet (RRP £500), and £500 cash settlement. I do not feel this is unreasonable bearing in mind the fact that my father had purchased a new car for over £40k which evidently had  a fault with the brakes when it was driven off the forecourt. However, Coopers at Colchester would not meet our request. Yes, they did make an offer that was approximately half-way, but bearing in mind the reasonable request we'd made, it now becomes a matter of principle. So, my question is, what is BMW's view-point on this? Do you not feel a customer should be entitled to compensation when they've purchased a brand new car with faulty brakes? We're not talking about a minor cosmetic issue here - we're talking about a serious safety issue. I understand we have a warranty to cover us for the vehicle developing a fault. However, the vehicle did not develop a fault - it had it from day one. I'd be grateful for your thoughts on this please.

I had a very scary experience last night. I was driving home & it was a bit chilly. So I turned on my seat warmer in my car. After a few minutes, I had a pain in my behind. I touched my seat & it was super hot. So I thought to turn off my seat warmer. I was still feeling uncomfortable so I rushed home. As I got closer to home, I could smell something burning. 

I got home quickly. So...

The seat warmer had burned a hole in my leather seat. It burned a hole thru all my layers of clothing & left a painful red mark on my body. It hurts to sit today :-(

As I was shaking from this incident last night, my family found the link below. It has happened before! :-((

I drive a BMW X3. I take good care of my car & take it in for servicing to the BMW dealership every 6 months. Never once, have they ever mentioned this problem or told me about any type of recall. 

I am upset. I am livid. Thank goodness I turned off the seat warmer. Thank goodness that my clothes didn't get completely set on fire. Thank goodness that my daughters were not in the car & that I didn't get into an accident. 

If this has happened before, why wouldn't BMW issue a recall? I will be calling the dealership & writing a letter to BMW Canada tomorrow. 

Here is a picture of my car seat. I have spared you the vision of my red behind :-) Sigh...first world problems...

Hello,

because I don't know if anybody will read this or who will read this, I am writing this in general to BMW company.
I would like to write you about my love to BMW cars. I remember since I was a kid, that I've always turned my head around when one of your cars went pass me. I'm simply in love in BMW cars. The "kidneys" on the front of the car were always catching my look. And when you later look at the whole car, you simply run out of words. Also as a kid, when we were at the stores, if I saw BMW model car I wanted it. But because we are in a small country, there were not a lot of BMW model cars here. Through the time of me growing up, I've allowed other kids that came to our house to play with my model cars and I've also gave them some of them because they wanted them. I was always the kid who was generous and willing to help. But through all this time, I never gave my first model car which I still have. It is of course a bit damaged because other kids were also playing with it, but it is still with me as my motivation of maybe owning one in the future. Now this model is a bit outdated now, it is a BMW 325i, I think from 1993. But I still have it and I am also sending you a picture of it with my BMW formula 1 car that I also kept. 
Later when I grown up a bit, I was around 12-16 years old, my parents took me many times to BMW dealership in our town, so that I could admire your cars. I remember once when we got there and the seller asked if he can help us in any way and my dad said, that not for now but that he brought a future customer with him. Of course he was thinking me. Then I was old enough to drive on my own so I was starting to go by myself to dealership to see the cars. And when I met my girlfriend (we are now almost 7 years together) and we talked about cars I said that my dream is to have a BMW. Last year I took her again to dealership here in Maribor and showed her the cars. She also loves them but at least for now, they are out of our reach to have it. At that time I remember we were looking at BMW X5, brand new with M package. I loved it because I like big, massive cars. But my girlfriend was almost like on a slide when she was leaving the passenger seat (I am 202cm tall, she is 158cm). I practically love all BMWs but because of my size I mostly look after 5 series and X5. Hopefully I will be able to buy one in future. I just love them and I know that someday I will own one brand new. 
So this is my "short" story of my love and passion about BMW cars. And when I saw you've opened BMW Welt in Munich which is around 3 hours of drive from here, I have to see it. And I am planning to visit it this year.

Thank you for doing my dream cars and the most beautiful cars on planet!
Luka from Slovenia

#Chrysler, #Ford, #GeneralMotors, #Dodge, #Jeep, #Lincoln, #MercedesBenz, #Bmw   So far in 2014 there have been at least thirteen heatstroke deaths of children in vehicles; eleven confirmed as heatstroke and two are still pending official findings by the medical examiner. Last year, 2013, there were at least forty-four deaths of children in vehicles; thirty-nine which has been confirmed as heatstroke and five which, based upon the known circumstances, are most likely heatstroke (2013 list). In 2012 there were 34 deaths of children due to hyperthermia (heatstroke) after being left in or having gained access to hot cars, trucks, vans and SUV's. Since 1998 there have been at least 619 documented cases of heatstroke deaths of children in vehicles. This data and study shows that these incidents can occur on days with relatively mild (i.e., ~ 70 degrees F) temperatures and that vehicles can reach life-threatening temperatures very rapidly.

There are also far too many "close calls" that fortunately do not result in a tragic death

This morning I was driving to work and because of my car I was able to avoid an accident.  As I was passing a city bus on my right, out of the corner of my eye I saw a pedestrian walking across in front of the bus. Before I could react the car sounded a warning chime and stopped the car before I could.  The car managed to stop approximately 6" from the car in front of me.  

To think I thought about disabling the feature; so glad I didn't.

Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, 

mittlerweile wurde, nach mehrmaliger Rücksprache mit der BMW Niederlassung Nürnberg-Fischbach und Herrn Gschaider aus der BMW-Headquarter eine „Lösung“ gefunden. Wir konnten den X5 zurückgeben, jedoch gekoppelt mit der Bedingung ein mindestens gleichermaßen hochwertiges Fahrzeug wieder als 36-monatigen Leasingvertrag zu nehmen. Zu der Zeit hätten wir einen 116d benötigt, jedoch wurde eben dieses Fahrzeug als Anschlussvertrag verweigert, da die monatliche Rate als zu gering gesehen wurde.
Nach langen Überlegungen und angesichts der Tatsache, dass die Türen beim X5 immer noch während der Fahrten aufsprangen, haben wir uns der Sicherheit wegen, gezwungenermaßen für einen 7er entschieden. 
Dieser wurde nun als Fahrzeug im Anschlussvertrag akzeptiert. 
Das Fahrzeug wurde am 05.08.2016 in der BMW Niederlassung Nürnberg-Fischbach, Regensburger Str. 420, 90480 Nürnberg abgeholt. 

Und schon am ersten Tag gab es wieder Schwierigkeiten mit dem Fahrzeug. 

Am 18.08.2016 war das Fahrzeug zum ersten mal in der Werkstatt: 

Sitzlüftung hat Geräusche gemacht, da der Ventilator unter den beiden vorderen Sitzen die Seitenwände berührt hatten. ( Hierfür war das Fahrzeug mehr als 3 mal in der Werkstatt) 
2.   Fahrassistent fällt immer wieder aus
3.  Gestensteuerung betätigt sich automatisch, obwohl keine Geste gemacht wurde
4.  Park Distance Control bremst das Fahrzeug beim Rückwärtsfahren ruckartig ab, obwohl keine Gegenstand im Weg steht. 
5. Lenkradheizung war defekt und hat nicht ausreichende Hitze entwickelt
6. Das Fahrzeug zeigt an, dass Motorölstand zu hoch ist, obwohl kein Öl nachgefüllt wurde
7. Beleuchtungsanlage (Laserlicht) auf einmal defekt. 

8. !!!!!!!!!! Das Fahrzeug qualmt seit dem 31.12.2016 immer und immer wieder!!!!!!!! 
Der Rauch gelangt vom Motorraum in die Fahrerzelle und in den Kofferraum! 
Während der Rauchentwicklung arbeitet die Lüftung im Motorraum auf Hochtouren, obwohl der Motor bereits abgestellt wurde. 
Das Fahrzeug wurde beim 1. mal von der Pannenhilfe abgeschleppt.
Seit dem hat das Fahrzeug mehr als 20 mal gequalmt. Dokumentiert wurde der Defekt 14 mal mit genauer Zeit- und Ortsangabe. Zusätzlich haben wir auch Videomaterial, dass den Schaden belegen kann. 
Das Fahrzeug war mindestens 3 mal wegen eben dieser Rauchentwicklung in der Werkstatt der 
BMW Niederlassung Nürnberg-Fischbach, Regensburger Str. 420, 90480 Nürnberg. 3 mal konnte der Defekt nicht behoben werden. 
Es macht keinen Spaß bei den Fahrten im Winter immer das Fenster offen haben zu müssen. Der Rauch verursacht bei den Insassen Schwindelgefühle und Übelkeit. 
Wir haben die Verkaufsleitung der BMW Niederlassung Nürnberg-Fischbach, Regensburger Str. 420, 90480 Nürnberg mit dieser Tatsache konfrontiert und wurde nur wieder die leere Versprechung gemacht, dass die Werkstatt sich dieses mal (nach mehrmaligen Versuchen) bemüht, den Fehler wirklich zu beseitigen. 

Wir wollten nun nicht mehr mit dem Fahrzeug fahren und das Fahrzeug zurückgeben bzw. vom Vertrag zurücktreten, da der Rauch im Fahrzeug kein zumutbarer Zustand ist. 
Der Wunsch vom Vertrag zurückzutreten wurde wie erwartet belächelt und man belehrte uns, dass ein Rücktritt nur mit einem gravierenden Fahrzeugfehler vereinbar wäre.
JETZT stellen wir uns die Frage, ob den Rauch in der Fahrerzelle bei einer Vielzahl von Autofahrten denn kein gravierender Defekt ist? Den beissenden Geruch konnten sowohl die Meister aus der Werkstatt als auch unser Verkäufer noch Tage danach riechen. 
Warum macht BMW so etwas mit seinen Kunden?!!!!

Auswegslos haben wir uns nun Hilfe bei einem Anwalt geholt. Wir haben uns an die BMW Financial und an die BMW Niederlassung Nürnberg-Fischbach, Regensburger Str. 420, 90480 Nürnberg gewendet. 
Die BMW Financial meint nur, dass sie nicht der richtige Ansprechpartner für so einen Fall sind. 
Die BMW Niederlassung Nürnberg-Fischbach, Regensburger Str. 420, 90480 Nürnberg stellt sich einfach quer uns lässt wiederum ihren Anwalt uns mitteilen, dass es keinen Grund gibt, vom Vertrag zurückzutreten. 
Wir sollen das Fahrzeug solange fahren, bis evtl. kein Rauch mehr auftritt. 
Das ist doch nicht euer ernst?!!! 

Anstatt sich bestürzt bei den Kunden zu entschuldigen und eine zufrieden stellende Lösung zu unterbreiten, verstecken die sich hinter einem Anwalt und lassen uns ausrichten, dass wir das Fahrzeug solange bewegen sollen, bis kein Rauch mehr entsteht. Die BMW Niederlassung Nürnberg-Fischbach, Regensburger Str. 420, 90480 Nürnberg riskiert bewusst die Gesundheit ihrer eigentlich treuen Kunden. 

Bitte leiten Sie diesen Sachverhalt umgehend an Herrn Gschaider aus der Kundenzufriedenheits-Abteilung

Aber wenigstens am Wochenende könnte man die Strecke nutzen! Was ich eig damit sagen möchte, das mehr Jungendliche und zudem jegliche Art von Motorsportler sich einsetzten um sowas zu erhalten. Hallo Leute, ich war der größte BMW Fan aller Zeiten. Aber
inzwischen bin ich echt enttäuscht von BMW.. Hatte meinen BMW116i zur Inspektion in eine BMW Fachwerkstatt gegeben. Bei der Abholung erfuhr ich die Hiobsbotschaft: Motorschaden!!!
Neben der Rechnung für die Inspektion bekam ich einen fetten Kostenvoranschlag für den Einbau eines Austauschmotors 😡. Das Auto ist 5 Jahre alt und hat ca 90T km.. Bei ca 70T km war das Zeichen für den Motor auf dem Display schon erschienen. Die Garantie ist klar abgelaufen. Alle Kulanzanfragen wurden von München abgelehnt, kein bisschen Entgegenkommen!! Ich fahre seit fast 15 Jahren nur BMW. So eine Sauerei. Mit meinem vorherigen BMW 316ti Compact hatte ich gleiche Problem. Der ist irgendwann einfach nicht mehr angesprungen. Den hatte ich auch mit null km gekauft und der hat auch keine 100 tausend km gehalten.. Inzwischen vertrete ich die Meinung: außen hui und innen pfui (Billigschrott eingebaut, Splitter im Öl, weil sich der Behälter auflöst, Steuerungskette zu dünn, ...)  👎👎👎
Nie wieder BMW!!!

Wo andere sich des heutigen Fußball-Spiels erfreuen, muss ich mich leider schwarz ärgern. "Freude am Fahren" so lautet euer langjähriges Motto. Ich frage mich grade ob das ironisch gemeint ist. Wieso? Bei meinem 1er BMW Facelift, der noch zu den jungen Fahrzeugen zählt, wurde festgestellt dass meine Ölwanne komplett durchgerostet ist. Ich frage mich wieso das passieren kann? Immerhin ist der Wagen regelmäßig in sämtlichen Inspektionen und wird pfleglich behandelt. Mir ist zudem auch bewusst, dass man für die Premiummarke BMW durchaus mal mehr bezahlt, aber knapp 700 für den Austausch mit Ölwechsel? Ist das euer ernst? Man muss die Vorderachse ausbauen und den Motor anheben, damit man sie überhaupt tauschen kann? Meine Werkstadt sagte mir sie haben sowas bei einem jungen Fahrzeug noch nicht gesehen. Ich wollte eigentlich gerne in den Urlaub. Das wars dann mit der Freude am Fahren. Vielleicht habt ihr ja Interesse daran, meine Stimmung wieder zu heben. Ich schreib das hier in aller Höflichkeit, bin aber sehr verärgert! Vielleicht kann ich ja mal nen Wochenende nen i8 fahren?:) Viele Grüße und danke für eine mögliche Antwort.
Was für eine Freude am fahren!!! (330d GT mit M Paket :)))) )

Liebes BMW-Team,
ich hab da mal eine Frage an Euch.
Warum würdet Ihr aus Kulanz die Kosten für meinen neuen iDrive-Controller übernehmen, aber nicht die Kosten für den Einbau, wofür mein Vertragshändler 140€ will?
Ich bin kein kleinlicher Mensch, aber eine messerscharfe Kante an einem Innenraumteil, was ja eindeutig kein Verschleißteil ist (vor allem nicht bei einem 43 Monate alten 320i), ist meiner Meinung nach nicht gerade das beste standing für einen Premiumhersteller.   
Der iDrive-Controller ist eindeutig mangelhaft von Eurem Lieferanten geliefert worden.
Warum lässt sich BMW den Einbau nicht von diesem Lieferanten bezahlen?
Versteht mich jetzt nicht falsch, ich bin mit meinem BMW ansonsten super zufrieden, bereue den Kauf nicht und bin auch dankbar, dass Ihr die Ersatzteilkosten übernehmen wollt.
Ich würde mich freuen, wenn Ihr mir meine Fragen beantwortet.

Mein neuer F31 M-Performance ist wirklich toll. Meistens auch das Prof.- Navi. Hab vorgestern leider feststellen müssen, dass der BMW Hotline service leider nicht der Qualität des Autos entspricht.

Was vorgefallen ist:
1) Fahrt von Österreich - Krems an der Donau nach Salzgitter.
    a) leider nur eine strecke durch Tschechien und eine            andere durch Frankfurt. Gut B6N is immer noch nicht in den Karten digitalisiert, schade aber nicht zu ändern 
    b) Also Passau als Ziel eingegeben damit ich nicht durch Prag fahren muss. (Schnelle Route, nichts meiden)
2) Alles zuerst gut. Keine Staus, die sonne scheint. 
3) Plötzlich werde ich von der Autobahn heruntergeführt und immer auf kleinere Starßen geroutet. (siehe Bild)
4) Angehalten Navi aus. 10 Min gewartet - Navi an - Route neu berechnet
5) Aber der schrecken endet leider nicht. Am ende stehe ich auf einer Straße wo mein BMW gerade so draufpasst. 
6) Hotline angerufen - Gespräch verlief abgekürzt so:
Haben sie ihre navioptionen angeschaut - Ja
Haben sie neugestartet -Ja
Ich gebe das an die Fachabteilung weiter - Das bringt mich aber hier nicht weiter
Warte sie bitte es wird sich in den nächsten Minuten jemand bei ihnen melden - gut 
7) Bis heute hat sich leider keiner Gemeldet.
8) Also iPhoneRaus und mit iphone zur Autobahn navigiert. Von da an nur nach Strassenschildern.
9) Da es mir keine Ruhe gelassen hat, heute nochmal angerufen und danach gefragt. Gespräch verlief abgekürzt so:
Ja tut mir wirklich leid. -> Ja, war wirklich nicht so schön, dass sich keiner gemeldet hat
Ihre Frage ist aber in der Fachabteilung -> Das ist schön bringt mich jetzt nicht weiter
Tut mir Leid

Fazit:
Erwarte von einem Auto jenseits von 70K und einer Hotline einen Besseren Service. 
Und vor allem, dass ich nicht in einer Notlage noch verarscht werde.

Los carros mas mas agenciados de Colombia! Es asi como me entregan el carro después de sacarlo del taller! Lleno de grasa en el asiento trasero. Una vez dejaron una caja de cartón de un repuesto dentro del motor ( de lo cual tengo fotos también ) llevo esperando 8 meses un repuesto con mi carro parqueado y lo pidieron mal! No era la referencia. Ahora debo esperar mas tiempo. por otro lado un repuesto que pidieron por otro tema desde febrero, me dicen que debo esperar otro mes ( parece que se les olvido importarlo y hoy 2 meses después que llamo a ver si llegó creo que se dan cuenta que no lo pidieron). En fin comprar un BMW y cualquier daño debes esperar como es mi caso de tres a cuatro meses si no es mas con tu carro guardado Por que no tienen los respuestos o los piden equivocadamente. En servicio al
Cliente escribes y nadie te responde por tu caso. Y para rematar recibes tu carro en el taller para llevarlo a guardarlo en tu casa y te lo entregan manchado de grasa.
